facts.text: This is Civil Appeal No. 142 of 1956.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 142 of 1956. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated September 13, 1954, of the Labour Appellate Tribunal of India  Calcutta Bench  in Appeal No. Cal-87 of 1953.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and order dated September 13, 1954 of Labour Appellate Tribunal of India Calcutta Bench in Appeal No. Cal-87 of 1953.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated September 13, 1954, of the Labour Appellate Tribunal of India  Calcutta Bench  in Appeal No. Cal-87 of 1953. N. Sanyal, Additional Solicitor--General of India, B. Dadachanji, S. N. Andley and Rameshwar Nath, for the appellants.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on November 5, 1957 by BHAGWATI J.

anchor.surface_text: 1957. November 5. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by BHAGWATI J.-This appeal with special leave arises out of an application made by the appellant to the Industrial Tribunal, Bihar under s. 33 of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947  hereinafter referred to as the Act , seeking permission to discharge the respondents from its employ.

facts.text: Appellant made application to Industrial Tribunal Bihar under s.33 Industrial Disputes Act 1947 seeking permission to discharge respondents from employ.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by BHAGWATI J.-This appeal with special leave arises out of an application made by the appellant to the Industrial Tribunal, Bihar under s. 33 of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947  hereinafter referred to as the Act , seeking permission to discharge the respondents from its employ. The respondents were in the employ of the appellant and were staying in a two storeyed house in the city of Patna which had been rented by the appellant for housing its workmen.

facts.text: Respondents were in employ of appellant and staying in two storeyed house in Patna rented by appellant for housing workmen.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents were in the employ of the appellant and were staying in a two storeyed house in the city of Patna which had been rented by the appellant for housing its workmen. On November 20, 1952, an occurrence took place in the said house wherein the respondents were involved.

facts.text: On November 20, 1952, an occurrence took place in the said house wherein respondents were involved.

anchor.surface_text: On November 20, 1952, an occurrence took place in the said house wherein the respondents were involved. Written reports of the said occurrence were sent on November 21, 1952, to the appellants Chief Engineer and the respondents were placed under suspension the same day.

facts.text: Written reports of the occurrence sent on November 21, 1952 to appellant's Chief Engineer.

anchor.surface_text: Written reports of the said occurrence were sent on November 21, 1952, to the appellants Chief Engineer and the respondents were placed under suspension the same day. An industrial dispute was then pending between the parties i.e., the appellant and its workmen before the Industrial Tribunal, Bihar, and the appellant therefore made an application to the said Tribunal under s. 33 of the Act for permission to dismiss the respondents on the ground of misconduct as per cl. 17 b  viii  of the appellants Standing Orders.

facts.text: Respondents placed under suspension on November 21, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: and the respondents were placed under suspension the same day. An industrial dispute was then pending between the parties i.e., the appellant and its workmen before the Industrial Tribunal, Bihar, and the appellant therefore made an application to the said Tribunal under s. 33 of the Act for permission to dismiss the respondents on the ground of misconduct as per cl. 17 b  viii  of the appellants Standing Orders.

facts.text: Industrial dispute pending between appellant and its workmen before Industrial Tribunal Bihar.

anchor.surface_text: An industrial dispute was then pending between the parties i.e., the appellant and its workmen before the Industrial Tribunal, Bihar, and the appellant therefore made an application to the said Tribunal under s. 33 of the Act for permission to dismiss the respondents on the ground of misconduct as per cl. 17 b  viii  of the appellants Standing Orders. On November 27, 1952, the respondents also made an application before the said Tribunal under s. 33A of the Act inter alia on the ground that their suspension by the appellant as aforesaid was a breach of s. 33 of the Act.

facts.text: Appellant made application under s.33 to Industrial Tribunal for permission to dismiss respondents for misconduct per cl.17(b)(viii) Standing Orders on November 21, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: On November 27, 1952, the respondents also made an application before the said Tribunal under s. 33A of the Act inter alia on the ground that their suspension by the appellant as aforesaid was a breach of s. 33 of the Act. On December 6, 1952, the appellant made an application before the said Tribunal stating that on a reconsideration of the facts of the case of the respondents the original prayer for permission to dismiss the the respondents was number being pressed, and for the ends of justice it would be sufficient if the appellant was granted permission to discharge the respondents under cl. 14 a  of the Standing Orders instead of the original prayer for dismissal under cl. 17 b  viii  thereof.

facts.text: On November 27, 1952, respondents made application under s.33A to Tribunal claiming suspension was breach of s.33.

anchor.surface_text: On November 27, 1952, the respondents also made an application before the said Tribunal under s. 33A of the Act inter alia on the ground that their suspension by the appellant as aforesaid was a breach of s. 33 of the Act.

facts.text: On December 6, 1952, appellant made application to Tribunal to seek permission to discharge under cl.14(a) instead of dismiss under cl.17(b)(viii).

anchor.surface_text: On December 6, 1952, the appellant made an application before the said Tribunal stating that on a reconsideration of the facts of the case of the respondents the original prayer for permission to dismiss the the respondents was number being pressed, and for the ends of justice it would be sufficient if the appellant was granted permission to discharge the respondents under cl. 14 a  of the Standing Orders instead of the original prayer for dismissal under cl. 17 b  viii  thereof. This application was resisted by the respondents.

facts.text: Industrial Tribunal made award on May 14, 1953 dismissing respondents' s.33A application and granting appellant permission to discharge respondents with one month's pay in lieu of notice within 15 days.

anchor.surface_text: The Industrial Tribunal, however, entertained the same and after hearing the parties duly made its award on May 14, 1953, dismissing the respondents application under s. 33A of the Act and granting the appellant permission to discharge the respondents from its employ with effect from the date of the order on payment to the respondents of one months pay in lieu of numberice within 15 days therefrom.

facts.text: Respondents appealed to Labour Appellate Tribunal Calcutta against IT order.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents carried an appeal against the said order of the Industrial Tribunal granting the appellants application under s. 33 of the Act before the Labour Appellate Tribunal of India, Calcutta.

facts.text: Labour Appellate Tribunal held no substantial question of law but entertained appeal, found no misconduct under cl.17(b)(viii), set aside IT permission, but no reinstatement as notice given.

anchor.surface_text: The Labour Appellate Tribunal was of the opinion that the appellant had alleged misconduct against the respondents and companyld number be allowed to adopt the expedient of terminating their services by giving numberice for the requisite period or payment of salary in lieu of numberice and that the Industrial Tribunal, therefore, ought number to have entertained the application for amendment of the prayer of the original application in which the appellant wanted to dismiss the respondents for misconduct. This according to the Labour Appellate Tribunal was a substantial question of law and it therefore entertained the appeal.

facts.text: Appellant argued before Supreme Court no appeal lay to LAT under s.7 Industrial Disputes Appellate Tribunal Act 1950.

anchor.surface_text: Shri H. N. Sanyal, appearing for the appellant, has urged in the fore-front the companytention that numberappeal from the order of the Industrial Tribunal lay to the Labour Appellate Tribunal under s. 7 of the Industrial Disputes  Appellate Tribunal  Act, 1950.

facts.text: Respondents argued discharge was punitive due to misconduct under cl.17(b)(viii), not cl.14(a), and was retrenchment under s.2(oo).

anchor.surface_text: The answer of Shri P. K. Chatterjee on behalf of the respondents was that the action of the appellant in the matter of the termination of the services of the respondents was punitive in character, that the discharge of the respondents for which permission was sought by the appellant was a punitive discharge, that such discharge was by reason of the alleged misconduct of the respondents falling within cl. 17 b  viii  of the Standing Orders and number within cl. 14 a  thereof

facts.text: Supreme Court held December 6, 1952 application was a new application for discharge simpliciter under cl.14(a), abandoning dismissal.

anchor.surface_text: It must be numbered, however, that what the appellant purported to do by its application of December 6, 1952, was, in effect, to substitute another application asking for permission to discharge the respondents from its employ under el. 14 a  of the Standing Orders, thus abandoning the relief which it had prayed for in the original application.

facts.text: Industrial Tribunal found appellant's application for discharge bona fide and honest exercise of rights under cl.14(a), not punitive.

anchor.surface_text: The Industrial Tribunal, however, expressly recorded the finding that the application for leave to discharge the respondents from its employ was bona fide and what the appellant did by making the application dated December 6, 1952, was actuated by an honest motive of exercising its right to discharge the respondents under el. 14 a  of the Standing Orders instead of visiting upon the respondents the penalty of dismissing them from its employ under el. 17 b  viii  thereof.

facts.text: Supreme Court held no substantial question of law arose, LAT had no jurisdiction to entertain appeal.

anchor.surface_text: Once the Industrial Tribunal was of opinion that the application dated December 6, 1952, and the discharge of the respondents for which . the permission of the Industrial Tribunal was sought were in the honest exercise of the appellants rights, numberquestion of law, much less a substantial question of law companyld arise in the appeal filed by the respondents against the decision of the Industrial Tribunal and the Labour Appellate Tribunal was clearly in error when it entertained the appeal.

facts.text: Discharge simpliciter not retrenchment as definition in s.2(oo) came by Act 43 of 1953 published Dec 23, 1953, after IT order May 14, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: The argument that the discharge of the respondents though patently it was a discharge simpliciter was, in substance, retrenchment within the meaning of the definition companytained in s. 2 oo  of the Act is equally untenable, for the simple reason that the term retrenchment was for the first time defined in the manner in which it has been done by an Ordinance promulgated in October 1953 which was followed by Act 43 of 1953 which was published in the Gazette of India on December 23, 1953.

facts.text: Supreme Court allows appeal, sets aside LAT decision, restores Industrial Tribunal order of May 14, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: We accordingly allow the appeal, set aside the decision of the Labour Appellate Tribunal and restore the order made by the Industrial Tribunal, Bihar, on date May 14, 1953.

issues.text: Whether an appeal lay from the order of the Industrial Tribunal to the Labour Appellate Tribunal under s. 7 of the Industrial Disputes (Appellate Tribunal) Act, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: Shri H. N. Sanyal, appearing for the appellant, has urged in the fore-front the contention that no appeal from the order of the Industrial Tribunal lay to the Labour Appellate Tribunal under s. 7 of the Industrial Disputes (Appellate Tribunal) Act, 1950.

issues.text: Whether the order of the Industrial Tribunal involved a substantial question of law.

anchor.surface_text: He contended that the said order was not a decision within the meaning of that expression in s. 7 and even assuming that it was so, the appeal neither involved any substantial question of law nor was it a decision in respect of any of the matters specified in sub-s. (1) (b) of that section.

issues.text: Whether the discharge of the respondents was a punitive discharge under cl. 17(b)(viii) or a discharge simpliciter under cl. 14(a) of the Standing Orders.

anchor.surface_text: The answer of Shri P. K. Chatterjee on behalf of the respondents was that the action of the appellant in the matter of the termination of the services of the respondents was punitive in character, that the discharge of the respondents for which permission was sought by the appellant was a punitive discharge.

issues.text: Whether the appellant could terminate the services without holding a proper enquiry by resorting to cl. 14(a) instead of cl. 17(b)(viii).

anchor.surface_text: that such discharge was by reason of the alleged misconduct of the respondents falling within cl. 17 b viii of the Standing Orders and not within cl. 14 a thereof and that the substantial question of law which arose in the appeal was whether the appellant could be allowed to adopt the expedient of terminating the services of the respondents, without going through the procedure of submitting a charge-sheet to the respondents and holding a proper enquiry.

issues.text: Whether the discharge amounted to retrenchment under s. 2(oo) of the Act, giving right of appeal under s.7 IDAT Act.

anchor.surface_text: The other answer made by Shri P. K. Chatterjee was that having regard to the definition of the term retrenchment to be found in s. 2 oo of the Act the discharge of the respondents by the appellant really amounted to retrenchment and retrenchment being one of the matters specified in sub-s. (1) (b) of s. 7 of the Industrial Disputes (Appellate Tribunal) Act, 1950, the respondents had a right of appeal to the Labour Appellate Tribunal.

issues.text: Whether the application dated December 6, 1952, was a bona fide exercise of right to discharge under cl. 14(a) or involved unfair labour practice or victimization.

anchor.surface_text: The Industrial Tribunal, however, expressly recorded the finding that the application for leave to discharge the respondents from its employ was bona fide and what the appellant did by making the application dated December 6, 1952, was actuated by an honest motive of exercising its right to discharge the respondents under cl. 14 a of the Standing Orders instead of visiting upon the respondents the penalty of dismissing them from its employ under cl. 17 b viii thereof.

arguments.claim: No appeal lay from the order of the Industrial Tribunal to the Labour Appellate Tribunal under s. 7 of the Industrial Disputes (Appellate Tribunal) Act, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: Shri H. N. Sanyal, appearing for the appellant, has urged in the fore-front the contention that no appeal from the order of the Industrial Tribunal lay to the Labour Appellate Tribunal under s. 7 of the Industrial Disputes  Appellate Tribunal  Act, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: nor was it a decision in respect of any of the matters specified in sub-s. (1) (b) of that section.

arguments.court_reasoning: No question of law arose once IT found honest exercise of rights.

arguments.claim: Termination was punitive discharge under cl.17(b)(viii) Standing Orders, not cl.14(a); appellant cannot terminate without charge-sheet and proper enquiry.

anchor.surface_text: The answer of Shri P. K. Chatterjee on behalf of the respondents was that the action of the appellant in the matter of the termination of the services of the respondents was punitive in character, that the discharge of the respondents for which permission was sought by the appellant was a punitive discharge, that such discharge was by reason of the alleged misconduct of the respondents falling within cl. 17 b  viii  of the Standing Orders and not within cl. 14 a  thereof and that the substantial question of law which arose in the appeal was whether the appellant could be allowed to adopt the expedient of terminating the services of the respondents, without going through the procedure of submitting a charge-sheet to the respondents and holding a proper enquiry

court_response_anchor.surface_text: duct of the respondents falling within cl. 17 b  viii  of the Standing Orders and number within cl. 14 a  thereof and that the substantial question of

arguments.court_reasoning: Dec 6, 1952 application substituted new prayer for discharge simpliciter under cl.14(a), abandoning dismissal; IT found bona fide, no unfair practice or victimization.

arguments.claim: Discharge amounted to retrenchment under s.2(oo) IDA, appealable under s.7(1)(b) IDAT Act.

anchor.surface_text: The other answer made by Shri P. K. Chatterjee was that having regard to the definition of the term retrenchment to be found in s. 2 oo  of the Act the discharge of the respondents by the appellant really amounted to retrenchment and retrenchment being one of the matters specified in sub-s. (1) (b) of s. 7 of the Industrial Disputes  Appellate Tribunal  Act, 1950, the respondents had a right of appeal to the Labour Appellate Tribunal.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: of exercising its right to discharge the respondents under el. 14 a  of the Standing Orders instead of visiting upon the respondents the penalty of di

arguments.court_reasoning: s.2(oo) definition introduced by Ordinance Oct 1953 and Act 43/1953 published Dec 23, 1953, after IT order of May 14, 1953; not applicable.

arguments.claim: Appellant alleged misconduct, could not adopt expedient of termination by notice under cl.14(a) instead; IT ought not to have entertained amendment of original application; this is substantial question of law.

anchor.surface_text: A preliminary objection was taken on behalf of the appellant before the Labour Appellate Tribunal that no substantial question of law was involved and as such the appeal was not maintainable. The Labour Appellate Tribunal was of the opinion that the appellant had alleged misconduct against the respondents and could not be allowed to adopt the expedient of terminating their services by giving notice for the requisite period or payment of salary in lieu of notice and that the Industrial Tribunal, therefore, ought not to have entertained the application for amendment of the prayer of the original application in which the appellant wanted to dismiss the respondents for misconduct. This according to the Labour Appellate Tribunal was a substantial question of law and it therefore entertained the appeal.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: duct of the respondents falling within cl. 17 b  viii  of the Standing Orders and number within cl. 14 a  thereof and that the substantial question of

arguments.court_reasoning: Application of Dec 6 was new application substituting discharge under cl.14(a), not amendment; bona fide exercise of right, no substantial question of law.

arguments.claim: Application dated Dec 6, 1952 for discharge under cl.14(a) was bona fide and honest exercise of right, not punitive.

anchor.surface_text: The Industrial Tribunal, however, expressly recorded the finding that the application for leave to discharge the respondents from its employ was bona fide and what the appellant did by making the application dated December 6, 1952, was actuated by an honest motive of exercising its right to discharge the respondents under cl. 14 a  of the Standing Orders instead of visiting upon the respondents the penalty of dismissing them from its employ under cl. 17 b  viii  thereof.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: payment of salary in lieu of numberice and thus resorting to el. 14 a  of the Standing Orders instead of cl. 17 b  viii  of the same. The other answer

arguments.court_reasoning: Court upheld IT finding; discharge simpliciter, no unfair labour practice or victimization.

arguments.claim: Dec 6, 1952 application was in effect a new application for permission to discharge under cl.14(a), abandoning original dismissal prayer.

anchor.surface_text: It must be noted, however, that what the appellant purported to do by its application of December 6, 1952, was, in effect, to substitute another application asking for permission to discharge the respondents from its employ under cl. 14 a  of the Standing Orders, thus abandoning the relief which it had prayed for in the original application.

arguments.claim: Once IT found Dec 6 application and discharge were honest exercise of rights, no question of law much less substantial question arose; LAT erred in entertaining appeal.

anchor.surface_text: Once the Industrial Tribunal was of opinion that the application dated December 6, 1952, and the discharge of the respondents for which the permission of the Industrial Tribunal was sought were in the honest exercise of the appellants rights, no question of law, much less a substantial question of law could arise in the appeal filed by the respondents against the decision of the Industrial Tribunal and the Labour Appellate Tribunal was clearly in error when it entertained the appeal.

arguments.claim: Discharge simpliciter was not retrenchment as s.2(oo) definition applied post IT order.

anchor.surface_text: The argument that the discharge of the respondents though patently it was a discharge simpliciter was, in substance, retrenchment within the meaning of the definition contained in s. 2 oo  of the Act is equally untenable, for the simple reason that the term retrenchment was for the first time defined in the manner in which it has been done by an Ordinance promulgated in October 1953 which was followed by Act 43 of 1953 which was published in the Gazette of India on December 23, 1953.

arguments.claim: No appeal lay to LAT as not in respect of matters in s.7(1)(b) IDAT Act.

anchor.surface_text: If, therefore, at the relevant period the discharge simpliciter could not be deemed to be retrenchment of the respondents by the appellant, the decision of the Industrial Tribunal could not be said to be one in respect of any of the matters specified in sub-s. (1) (b) of s. 7 of the Industrial Disputes  Appellate Tribunal  Act, 1950.

holdings.text: The application dated December 6, 1952 was, in effect, to substitute another application asking for permission to discharge the respondents under cl. 14(a) of the Standing Orders, abandoning the original prayer for dismissal under cl. 17(b)(viii).

anchor.surface_text: It must be noted, however, that what the appellant purported to do by its application of December 6, 1952, was, in effect, to substitute another application asking for permission to discharge the respondents from its employ under cl. 14 a  of the Standing Orders, thus abandoning the relief which it had prayed for in the original application.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation of the application as a new prayer substituting discharge simpliciter for dismissal, not mere amendment.

holdings.text: The Industrial Tribunal's finding that the application for discharge was bona fide and an honest exercise of right under cl. 14(a) instead of dismissal under cl. 17(b)(viii) is upheld.

anchor.surface_text: The Industrial Tribunal, however, expressly recorded the finding that the application for leave to discharge the respondents from its employ was bona fide and what the appellant did by making the application dated December 6, 1952, was actuated by an honest motive of exercising its right to discharge the respondents under cl. 14 a  of the Standing Orders instead of visiting upon the respondents the penalty of dismissing them from its employ under cl. 17 b  viii  thereof.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Explicit acceptance of lower tribunal's factual finding on motive, no evidence of oblique intent.

holdings.text: Discharge under cl. 14(a) is simpliciter and permissible if bona fide, not arbitrary, capricious, unfair labour practice or victimization; Industrial Tribunal only to check these aspects under s.33.

anchor.surface_text: The discharge of the respondents was a discharge simpliciter in exercise of the rights of the employer under cl. 14 a  of the Standing Orders and was not a punitive discharge under cl. 17 b  viii  thereof and if it was merely a discharge simpliciter, then, no objection could be taken to the same and the appellant would be well within its rights to do so, provided, however, that it was not arbitrary or capricious but was bona fide.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Application of employer rights under Standing Orders; limits on Tribunal inquiry to bona fides and fairness.

holdings.text: Once Industrial Tribunal found honest exercise of rights, no question of law, much less substantial question of law, arose; Labour Appellate Tribunal erred in entertaining the appeal under s.7 IDAT Act.

anchor.surface_text: Once the Industrial Tribunal was of opinion that the application dated December 6, 1952, and the discharge of the respondents for which . the permission of the Industrial Tribunal was sought were in the honest exercise of the appellants rights, no question of law, much less a substantial question of law could arise in the appeal filed by the respondents against the decision of the Industrial Tribunal and the Labour Appellate Tribunal was clearly in error when it entertained the appeal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Jurisdictional limit under s.7 requires substantial question of law; absent here due to factual findings.

holdings.text: Discharge simpliciter not retrenchment under s.2(oo) IDA as definition introduced by Ordinance October 1953 and Act 43/1953 published December 23, 1953, after Tribunal order of May 14, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: The argument that the discharge of the respondents though patently it was a discharge simpliciter was, in substance, retrenchment within the meaning of the definition contained in s. 2 oo  of the Act is equally untenable, for the simple reason that the term retrenchment was for the first time defined in the manner in which it has been done by an Ordinance promulgated in October 1953 which was followed by Act 43 of 1953 which was published in the Gazette of India on December 23, 1953.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Temporal application of statutory definition; not retrospective.

holdings.text: No appeal lay to Labour Appellate Tribunal under s.7 IDAT Act as neither substantial question of law nor on specified matters in s.7(1)(b).

anchor.surface_text: If, therefore, at the relevant period the discharge simpliciter could not be deemed to be retrenchment of the respondents by the appellant, the decision of the Industrial Tribunal could not be said to be one in respect of any of the matters specified in sub-s. (1) (b) of s. 7 of the Industrial Disputes  Appellate Tribunal  Act, 1950.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Lack of jurisdictional peg due to nature of order and absence of law question or listed matter.

holdings.text: Appeal allowed; Labour Appellate Tribunal decision set aside; Industrial Tribunal order of May 14, 1953 restored.

anchor.surface_text: We accordingly allow the appeal, set aside the decision of the Labour Appellate Tribunal and restore the order made by the Industrial Tribunal, Bihar, on date May 14, 1953.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Consequence of jurisdictional error and upholding lower findings.

anchor.surface_text: The Industrial Tribunal, however, expressly recorded the finding that the application for leave to discharge the respondents from its employ was bona fide and what the appellant did by making the application dated December 6, 1952, was actuated by an honest motive of exercising its right to discharge the respondents under cl. 14 a  of the Standing Orders instead of visiting upon the respondents the penalty of dismissing them from its employ under cl. 17 b  viii  thereof.
